I can't find the words for this game, because it screams awesomeness, fun, immersive RPG'esque universe and deep lore on the surface, but the presentation kind of buried it all and makes you wish that it could have been the best Deus Ex 2D game.

It has to be mentioned though that Oxeye is a small indie game studio, therefore it is totally understandable that they were not given all the time on their hands into polishing it even further. 
Nonetheless, you can still see the INSANE effort and work that has been put into making this game, which has to be recognised and praised upon.

Amazing work, Oxeye!

I'm playing through the single-player a second time with the recently added mod support update that adds keyboard&mouse in the game and I'm loving every second of it!

Even though it's not what I excpected it to be, I am still immensely satisfied with the game, the level editor and the mod support. And with just enough time and effort, I strongly believe it can be turned into an awesome 2D Deus Ex game that touches on the buried lore and universe, bringing it back to the surface.

It is just a matter of time. ;)

PS: I purchased the game during it's alpha developement and I don't regret any penny for it!

40240718.review:
Español:

Este juego es uno de los mejores juegos "shooter" de desplazamiento lateral actuales contando con una mecanica de tiempo bala algo que hasta entonces no me encontrado en ningun juego 2D, Un soundtrack muy bueno de musica elctronica, una jugabilidad sublime como rodar para deviar las balas, apuntar aotomaticamente con shift al objetivo que favorezca mas al jugador o golpear las granadas enemigas para mandarlas a volar etc. y los graficos aunque no son lo mas destacable son peciosos, La historia es buena e intrigante pero es algo corta y el multiplayer podria decir que es lo mejor pero no hay partidas disponibles en la mayoria del tiempo, ademas cabe mencionar que tiene unos minimos bugs pero rara vez te encontraras con uno.

En conclusion, el juego es exelente pero pasa desapercibido para la mayoria de jugadores ya que no le dan una oportunidad, Lo recomendo totalmente aunque si te parece elevado el precio puedes probar la demo para ver si te interesa.

English:

This game is one of the best current side scrolling "shooter" games, counting on a bullet time mechanic something that until then I did not find in any 2D game, a very good electronic music soundtrack, a sublime gameplay like rolling to devote bullets, aim aotomatically with shift to the target that favors the player more or hit the enemy grenades to send them to fly etc. and the graphics although they are not the most remarkable they are beautiful, The story is good and intriguing but it is short and the multiplayer could say that it is the best but there are no games available in most of the time, it is also worth mentioning that has a few bugs but you will rarely find one.

In conclusion, the game is excellent but it goes unnoticed for most players because they do not give it a chance. I recommend it totally, although if you think the price is high you can try the demo to see if it interests you.

38799871.review:
This game is great, and as everyone has pointed out, not nearly enough people play it. I remember when I bought it back when it was in alpha, and after testing it, was really pumped for it's release. The game itself did not disappoint at all, it's the most unique and fun 2D shooter I've ever played. What really got to me was how very few people play it and the servers were all dead, besides the occasional Wave Survival match. Still, while this game has insane potential for competitive multiplayer gameplay, the Singleplayer campaign alone makes it worth it : it's big, long, action-packed, full of secrets, and with a real sense of progression as you discover new areas and find more weapons to add to your collection. Classic Survival is, in my opinion, also a blast to play by yourself, and there's always the possibility to play local multiplayer. Of course, this requires you to gather a bunch of friends and some controllers, and us PC gamers may not always have many controllers available. If you do, however, then you'll have a ton of fun, because local multiplayer is really well-polished and one of the main features of the game, in fact. 

  Also, I should add that you will need a controller to properly play the game, and not just a cheap SNES replica, but a modern, full-featured controller. I personally use a Nintendo Switch pro controller because that's what I have available, you can also use Xbox controllers, PlayStation controllers, or if you don't have any of those, you can pick up a Logitech f310 for pretty cheap depending on where you live and it'll do the job just fine. If you don't have one and don't want to buy any hardware, then I guess you CAN survive on a keyboard, but it'll feel much, much better with a controller. 

   The game officially came out a year ago and never took off so I hardly believe the multiplayer situation will change much ; but while online gameplay is pretty much absent, there is an active community of modders and map-makers (because, by the way, the game includes a full-featured level design tool which is very powerful and probably what the devs used themselves) so in a way the game is not COMPLETELY dead.

  Basically, get this game if you're interested in singleplayer or local multiplayer, make some awesome maps and share them if you want to, don't get your hopes up for online multiplayer since it's often empty or only a couple of gamemodes have people playing them.

37987649.developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write your review. I'm not asking you to change your opinion of Cobalt, but I wanted to share some clarity to why WASD is a separate game:

WASD was designed to streamline the way players enter an online multiplayer match. Start the game and press play. Cobalt has both singleplayer and multiplayer, and each come with multiple modes and settings. Adding another game mode to Cobalt - with a completely new control scheme - would not help anyone.

Charging $6.99 for WASD was necessary. Oxeye Game Studio needs money to survive. We went to great lengths to include our early backers by giving the game for free to alpha players, and having a 10% bundle discount for all Cobalt players.

A lot of the work put into WASD is benefitting Cobalt as well. Cobalt currently has a beta branch (join our Discord to get access) that adds modding support and other fixes. We've already created a mod that adds mouse-aim to Cobalt, and when you play it you will discover why it was necessary to make WASD. This beta build will be put on the main branch "soon."

Thanks.

33780391.review:
A very cool little indie game that you can spend hours playing! Brought to you by Jeb and Co. at Mojang (the same group who made Minecraft), it features robots with consciences shooting and gibbing each other until one side is declared victorious in the local multiplayer, or simply flying solo, killing rouge bots in the campaign. The controls are very responsive and intuitive, controller-wise and on keyboard/mouse. I prefer to play this game with a controller for precise aiming and maneuvering (which, as a game enthusiast, I almost always despise because of the availability of a mouse on PC), so that is something to commend as well. The art is immersive and colorful, very well detailed, and will make you lose yourself quickly in the feel of it! My hours don't properly reflect how much I've played this game because it was in beta off of Steam for a good eight to twelve months, but that shouldn't be the only dependency on a person liking a game. Never had any technical issues playing at all, even in beta.

Overall, I give it an 8/10 for style and ingenuity! Very well made and will always go down as a classic for me. Worth a buy!

33681916.review:
[h1] tl;dr: Buy this game now, It's worth 20 dollars and more. [/h1]

This game deserves WAY more praise than it gets. It's 2D sidescrolling action platforming at its finest, however be warned that this game doesn't have conventional play by any means. It's main combat style is heavily oriented around this game's unique Rolling mechanic. You don't aim with a mouse, so the only way to shoot above or below you is rolling, not to mention it can deflect bullets, increse speed, chain combo kills, stomp opponents, and entertain me for hours!

Not to mention its SUPERB soundtrack and graphics! The lighting is incredible, the sound design is top-notch, and its production quality is above and beyond any other 2D sidescrolling platformer I've EVER played! It has endless polish, a banger of a soundtrack, a beautiful artstyle, tons of content, online multiplayerplayer, a huge story mode I have yet to finish and SO much more!

Althought its difficulty is immense, and the difficulty curve is hard to cope, I think this only adds to the experience. It requires split-second timing and quite a lot of strategic planning with how you approach certain enemies with different weapons, but really that's more of a plus than many negative reviews give it credit for. If you're struggling with this game, don't feel discouraged! Skill comes with practise, which comes with time! I'd reccomend the arcade mode challenges to practise your skills.

All in all, it's a great game. Extremely well made. My biggest quip and my only problem is how  it was marketed. Cobalt gets barely any spotlight, and as such suffers greatly. Mojang, publisher of Cobalt, developed the biggest hit game in history, Minecraft, and yet they totally failed when trying to raise Cobalt. It's a real mystery to me how it flew so low under the radar. Barely anybody plays it, so nobody's online half the time. It's a real shame.

Anyways, buy it. It's worth your time, and it's more than worth 20$. Also, thanks for sticking around and reading this whole review, I really appreciate your dedication. If you got this far, you deserve to play Cobalt, so do yourself a favor and buy it. You won't regret it.

tl;dr

Es un juego plataforma super divertido. La posibilidad de esquivar balas, rebotarlas, rechazar misiles, etc es bien suavee. Garantiza varias horas de diversion. IMO.

Conoci cobalt gracias a mi hno que lo vio  no se donde. Me lo mostro, y a juzgar por los videos se veia divertido. Lo compramos y empezamos a jugar; eso antes que estuviera aqui en steam, alfa o beta algo asi. Nos divertiamos mucho jugando en survival, y es que todo es algo tan diferente. De por si me gustan los juegos de plataformas, pero Cobatl me dio una experiencia diferente, el poder esquivar las balas, regresar misiles, el bullet time, las diferentes armas, muchas cosas que lo hacen muy entretenido; la forma en que gira me da la sensacion de ninja cuando usas armas de mano para atacar, heh. Despues que salio la version final con la historia y el multiplayer pfft que locura. Lo disfrute mucho, digo disfrute porque actualmente no dedico mucho tiempo para jugar, tanto que se volvio de mis juegos favoritos. De hecho es el juego en el que tengo mas horas. De mi parte es altamente recomendado! (Y). 

P.D.: Escribo esta resena en espanol porque veo muy pocas y tengo la esperanza de que los usuarios de habla hispana se animen a darle una oportunidad a este juego tan chaka.

This game seemingly has an interesting athmosphere, music and writing SEEM great.
But i am not goijng further here and that has the following reasons:

1. The gameplay wants to be a twitch reaction action shooter. But the controls are a) seemingly different to be different and b) absolutely not made for twitch reaction gameplay.
The biggest point for this is that in twitch action combat you want to use the right weapon in the right situation. Let say you shoot an enemy in the distance and next you want to beat another enemy close to you over the head with the shovel. Instead that you simply have a closecombatbutton in this game you need to first change to the closecombat weapon and then use it. Same counts when using grenades.

2. Autoaim is a luckshot if it hits what you want to hit or if it works at all, especially when doing the rollmaneuver. Actually aiming isn't really a thing aside from you standing on the spot to do it which in the quick battles means you get killed on the spot.Actually hitting anything is a clunky mess.

3. Hope you are lucky punk! Because if you get killed in battle from one moment to another seems to be simply based on luck. A lot of the game is badly readable as in the overall design is done in a way that you can't really read what the enemys are doing next, you don't know if the reflect roll is gonna work this time or you suddenly die for some reason. You don't know if it is now better for you to ride animals or rather not (didn't seem helpfull but who knows). You get a lot of numbers for different items in shop and upgrademenues but it never FEELS like things are improving. The gameplayfeel is a mess if that makes sense. The game a has a lot of details in it (lockpicking doors, taming and riding mounts and birds, placing grenades and mines, talking to npcs and shopowner) but a lot of it dopesn't really feels fleshed out or serving any purpose. There is a lot of love to the detail in here that doesn't really add to the playability of the game. 

4. The worst thing however is the checkpoint system. AGAIN for some reason a gamedesigner meant the outdated concept of lifes is a good idea. But it is even more confusing. So you have a limited amount of lives to respawn on checkpoints. These respawns makes sure that you respawn while what you have done to the level so far (fought certain enemys, opened certain doors etc.) stays the way you left it. One of the problems of that is that you loose all weapons and items you had on the spot you died. So you are now going back to that spot while being underarmed for the enemys that may wait there for you, not to mention that some of the items seem to vanish iunstead of dropping. This adds to the already frustrating combat where you may survive or not, where the slow motion feature and the autoaim feature and the  repelling of projectiles and grenades may work... or even not.

The whole game feels... poorly thought out, the pacing seems off, tha game itself explains itself rather badly and the difficulty seems random and more luckbased then anything else.

Cobalt is a 2D shooter, where you are a robot thing called a Metalface,

[b] Singleplayer [/b]
The singleplayer is pretty good in my opinion, but there's not really a too much of a story, but it's definitely fun to fight the AI. (There are also NPCs that can sell you things like guns and upgrades)

[b] Multiplayer [/b]
This is probably what you are going to spend most of your gametime doing. Cobalt is best for local multiplayer because it is very fast paced, and kind of gives the atmosphere of a party game. 
There are multiple modes like Deathmatch, Capture the Plug (Capture the Flag) and Survival.

Survival is another gametype you will probably be playing a lot of. You start out with a little bit of money(Volts) and waves of increasing difficulty are sent to kill you. As the waves progress you can also buy new and better guns from weapons vendors, and upgrade them. 
The game also has bullet time, which is pretty funny sometimes.

[b] Level Editor [/b]
Cobalt comes with an intuitive level editor, so you can easily figure out how to use it by experimintation.

Iv'e played a LOT more that 15 hrs before the steam release too, the game definitely has replayability.

8/10 very good game

28601424.review:
Overall, this game is not what you'd probably expect out of a multi player shooter. 

It's combat system is very new and unusual, but pretty good. Damage is rather high, and it doesn't take a lot of shots to take out your opponent. There is lots of room for action movie style slow-mo bullet dodging and parkour. Don't give up right away, because you might not get it right away. However, if you do gain skill at the combat, you'll find it really fun.

As for game modes, there's Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Plug Slam (CTF), and Waves Survival, and Story mode. Waves survival is the most fun solo, but the others are pretty good too. Using the workshop, It's possible to obtain maps from alpha, which were in a game mode called Classic Survival, and this too is buckets of fun singleplayer. When I go solo, though, I find myself mostly playing Challenge modes and Survival modes, and I enjoy them a lot. Survival modes are even co-op. The story mode is not bad, but it's too easy for an experienced player. It could be a lot of fun if you were newer, but for people who've played tons of the Alpha, and become really good, it's just a little dull. There are also Combat challenges, Puzzle challenges, and Speed challenges. These are solo only. You can, however, compete scores with your friend. They're really fun to try and figure out how to do, and you'll end up playing them over and over again. You can even set the world record, if you're good enough. When the game first started, I actually briefly held one, so that was cool.

Get this game if you want a fun, simple time with awesome 2D action ranging from hardcore stealth to running and gunning, to slow mo badassery.
    By the way, I played a TON of alpha before the game was released, so my playtime does not well reflect my legitimacy to review.

26346184.review:
All right, I'm going to keep this fairly simple.

Cobalt is a blast. The singleplayer I found to be meh (there wasn't much there that was interesting - a lot of exploring environments that aren't particularly interesting, taking out a couple enemies here and there, maybe a miniboss or two . . . I dunno, I just wasn't very interested), but the multiplayer/arcade mode is phenomenal.

To be perfectly honest, there aren't a whole lot of people online at any given time. There are peak hours/days where you might get a full server, but my experience has mostly been starting a server and just playing against the bots until someone joins and you can play with one or two (sometimes three) other people for a little while. There's a variety of fun gamemodes, and while there's a bit of a steep learning curve (particularly because most of the people playing have been around for quite a while and are really good), the community has been very friendly. When I was still learning to play, this one guy switched to a different map and gamemode just to take the time to teach me what has proven to be the most valuable technique that I currently know.

The gameplay, though, is obviously the selling point. And oh, it sells. The fast-paced action, intense moments, slow-mo exchanges of gunfire, impressively challenging bots and phenomenal players, all make for a wonderful experience, and I cannot tell you how many times I've wished that I record whenever I play the game, not just for my own awesome moments, but ones that I've seen other people make.

Is $20 a reasonable price for this game? Yeah, I think it probably is. But I would absolutely recommend it to anyone interested when it's $10 or less - it's a lot of fun!

[list]

[*]одиночный аркадный режим, целью которого - стать на первых строчках лидеров, также включающий режимы сетевой игры с ботами;
[*]редактор уровней.

[list]

[*]очень низкий онлайн.
[/list]

24242574.review:
Cobalt is a fast paced, shooter/platformer with a great variety of things in it; from disco dancing to cracking safes, from grenade punching to high speed time challenges, it has it all.

It's graphics are relatively simple tile-to-tile, but when tiles are added together, can create an elegant plethora of style.

The combat its self seems complex and hard at first, but once you get the hang of it, you will find it all flows naturally without much difficulty. You can bounce enemy's bullets off your head to either redirect the bullet away, or (if well timed) bounce it straight back to them, dealing damage or even killing them; you can also punch or shoot grenades, sending them away from you or again, back at your opponent. Another important fact is that it has a "bullet time" feature, where the time of the local area is slowed to allow more complicated maneuvers.

When it comes to single player, it features a complete campaign and challenges, with a scoreboard to compare yourself to other players.

The multiplayer is where this game truly shines though, you can team up in survival against wave after wave of enemies, or battle it out in one of the P.V.P. modes. It includes a deathmatch gametype,
a "team strike" in which you are put in teams, fight, and then spend points on a better loadout, first team to eleven rounds won wins,
and a "plug slam" which is what you get if you crossed football (soccer) rugby, or American football with their deathmatch gametype, their are two goals (one for each team) and a "plug" in the center, once you pick up the plug, you must throw it into the opposing teams goal, however, you cannot shoot when holding the plug, so you must avoid any confrontation with the other team that you can.
It also contains a bot feature, so if their are not enough players, AI can fill their place.
Any of these game types can also be played with just these bots and no other players if one so wishes to do so.

All in all, Cobalt is a game that you can, and will, spend many hours in, trying to shave the second off that one speed challenge you just can't seem to get under mountain hammer time, obtaining a higher score then your friends on one of the combat challenges, getting 100% on the campaign, or even just matches online.

24149133.review:
I've been following this game since beta and holy ****. I'm proud of what it has become. It had potential back then and they surely used that potential. 

Cobalt is a 2D Shooter-Platformer. 
While those are fun by themselves, Cobalt overdid it and added a enormous amount of features to enhance that genre. 
A few of these features are:

> The bullet-deflecting dodge-rolls, which also change the direction of the character as he rolls, allowing for incredible trick-shots or other fun things like using a high-powered weapon to roll and shoot the ground, launching you upwards or forwards, depending on where you are facing.

> Time-distorting "Reaction Enhancer" which automatically slows down time whenever an iminent threat is about to obliterate you. Sure, this may sound like something that would make a game way too easy... But that is not the case at all. The slow-mo surely allows you and others to decide what to do in life-or-death situations that would normally destroy you before one could even see what happened, but you are slowed too and often these situations are not evadeable.

> Semi-Open-world story mode. It's episodic, unlocking more areas as you progress in the history and "To the right" is usually the correct way to go. But there are always plenty of ways to go where you want, depending on what kind of character you are building for yourself. The worlds are also full of secrets to be found and the occasional side-quest that will give you rewards beyond money, like yet another way to approach the boss. 

> Character and weapon customization is a very important thing is this. It allows you to choose if you'll be the kind of character that takes it in the face and laugh at their puny guns, the guy who snipes them from afar before they even see you, the ninja that causes the local guards to disappear misteriously even few seconds, etc. Weapons and equipment can also be upgraded to have bigger magazines, laser-sights, scopes, silencers, etc. For a 2D shooter, this is an impressive feat.

Multiplayer is also fantastic with friends, specially on lan-parties. 

The bad? Maybe two things. The first one, which didn't bother me but can be a problem to some, is the learning-curve since Cobalt has odd button patterns for a first timer and can get confuzing, but once they are mastered, you'll get shot in the face less. The second is a minor problem, where if you TAB out of the game while in full-screen, it cuts the window and move it up, making it impossible to readjust without quitting the game and opening it again.

I would certainly give this game a 10/10.

ALRIGHT, lets get started...

Damn this guy is funny to play with, I've never really enjoyed reading interactions between characters, but this little robot robbed me a LOT of giggles, damn it's amusing... hahaha

2) The combat is F-U-N as hell and intense if you have at least something that resembles a brain inside your head... People are crying about controllers but even playing online with a keyboard I've won several matches against guys using XBox controllers, so yeah, get good and stop bitching, IT IS WORTH IT... 22606627.review:
Cobalt is an achievement. This is something that can only be fully understood once you can play multiplayer deathmatch at sufficiently high level. I have played single player for 4 or 5 hours, but all of the rest was multiplayer deathmatch.

Because the combat in Cobalt is deep and refined.

Each minute decision of when to spin, when to jump, when to air jump, and on which direction, creates a *very* fluid and natural response in the player character. The result is that movement alone is a skill that you can spend hours upon hours mastering — and the range of possibilities is so vast that after practicing just movement for many hours (yes, I spent several hours jumping around alone in DM maps) the skill cap is still nowhere to be found.

On top of this, every weapon is its own delicious little niche of discovery. Take grenades, for instance. The path trajectory of grenades is influenced by your movement in multiple ways: (1) grenades will go further the longer you press the fire button; (2) grenades will inherit the speed at which your character is moving; (3) spinning allows you to throw grenades on any direction by correctly timing the release button, and (4) some grenades bounce off walls, some explode on impact, some get stuck to walls. These four factors multiply into *so many* possibilities! With the right sense of the thing, you can learn to place a grenade almost anywhere at almost any moment, with a good idea of when it will blow up. Someone is about to fall on top of you? Spin an explode-on-impact grenade directly above while falling down. Opposite team is rushing through a fixed path in large numbers? Spin a grenade in a long, tall arc to stall them from a safe position. Grenade throwing is a huge skill all in itself, and can make or break an entire game.

Or take punching, for another unpopular example. To properly punch your adversary requires a mix of timing, prediction (of what he will do), jumping and spinning (to avoid his shots), so that if you can do it properly the visual end-result looks as if a robot ninja from hell is warping a vortex of pure kung-fu on his unwitting prey. If you add on top of that that punching the ground or the wall will push you away from it, you will come to realize that even the damned melee weapon is beautifully designed.

And I could go on... I'm sure there is plenty of things I didn't discover!

Let me give you two parting tips for playing multiplayer: You can configure your keyboard to have three different keys for immediately shooting each category of weapon (melee, fire, grenade), and three different keys for selecting the weapon in each category. (By default cobalt you have three keys for selecting the weapon in each category and one fire key to fire the weapon in the category that was last selected; this will become a roadblock if you keep at it)

Much luck and have fun,
Bruno

22509333.review:
Cobalt is a fun enough action platformer shooter, yet felt like a case of quantity over quality.

It starts out like a pleasant Metroidvania, where you're sent to explore a lost colony to find out what happened. It proceeds much like a Metroidvania, except that the journey is a purely linear one with no abilities to unlock to open new areas to explore.

The controls are a little odd. You have to hold Up or Down in order to aim, which stops your movement unless you're sliding down the hill. To melee you have to first hit X to switch to melee and then hit RT to attack, instead of X just being a dedicated melee button.

And then we come to the first boss fight, an exercise in going around a large room activating consoles while killing constantly respawning enemies. It's about as fun as it sounds, and it first introduces Cobalt's frenetic, chaotic combat, where you need to roll to deflect shots, shoot / hit incoming explosives to deflect them, and to pray. Success seems equal parts skill and luck as you're rolling and blasting and hoping you kill everything.

And after defeating the first boss, you get to do it all over again 5 more times, go through a similar set of maps to reach the same exact boss fight, just in a different room with different respawning enemies.

This is where the quantity over quality makes itself felt. Each of the 6 areas plays out exactly the same, with the same exact un-interesting boss fight at the end of each one. There's a plethora of weapons to collect, each with more stats than you'd find in an ARPG, but few are truly memorable. There are likewise armor upgrades, 5 items for 5 slots, that feature such dramatic differences as a 0.4 increase in damage reduction. 

There are even animal enemies to summon or tame and ride, but they're all disposable.

And then there are bugs, from small things like how the Time Guardian never introduced himself and yet my character referred to him as such, to the game breaking bug after beating the 2nd boss fight. An item was supposed to spawn, but didn't, leaving me stuck and having to quit out and repeat the fight. I similarly got stuck in another area where I couldn't get out and couldn't progress until I brute forced a combination lock.

Cobat is a platform-action game, and I hate the controls.

The game features a single-player campaign (can be played in coop), and multiplayer (local and online). It has a lot of features, but I can't get over the gameplay to appreciate anything else the game has to offer. Even accessing the campaign missions is slow and complicated.

If like me you are picky about controls, especially with games where you have to fire guns, you can give this one a pass.

22397397.review:
I can't recommend this game enough!

If the trailer is of any indication, this game is action-packed. Play story mode a bit (or a lot because there are loads of things to do), play a variety of gamemodes with your friends, including classic deathmatch, but also original gamemodes like Plug Slam, where the object is to get the 'ball' into the opponents goal by any means necessary (think throwing, shooting, exploding).

The singleplayer modes are plenty difficult, and you will come across situations where you're surrounded by legions of robots and because you were stupid like me, forget to stock up on ammo and have to resort to punching them to death (which is difficult but you feel like a badass when you succeed). This is one of the most fun parts of the game: you can do some crazy ninja shit and kick some real ass once you get good at it. And you never stop becoming better at it.

Most gamemodes are also available online, which is also loads of fun when you don't have friends. There is also an extremely expansive map editor, which can lead to amazing things if you think creatively. I learn new things everytime I open it.

The visuals are great and the weapons feel very satisfiying to use. The soundtrack is brilliant and really fits the game well! I've almost never had problems with lag either, and if I did, it was because I created a tower of about 30 giant mech robots all firing homing missiles stacked on top of eachother in the editor.

The only issue I see with the game (and it's arguable it's even the games fault) is that there aren't that many players. This means you'll only see a couple online games at a time. Still, the most popular gamemodes (TeamStrike and Survival) always have at least one open game so it's bearable.

21515902.review:
Review completo: http://criticalhits.com.br/cobalt-review/

Cobalt é um sidescroller com gameplay diferente que utiliza uma mecânica de slowdowns para que o jogador possa se esquivar e repelir tiros inimigos. O jogo contém diversas possibilidades de estratégia para que o jogador jogue do jeito que preferir, porém peca no modo história que é maçante e repetitivo, além de possuir sistema de tentativa e erro que o torna frustrante.

A magia do jogo está no multiplayer que possui diversos modos e mapas e permite que o jogador aprenda a jogar e se adaptar aos diferentes tipos de loadout que são oferecidos. A ação frenética e balas para todos os lados fazem o multiplayer ser um desafio bem prazeroso de se enfrentar e é com certeza um dos modos mais divertidos que já joguei.

Prós:
+Combate acelerado
+Divertido
+Possibilita que o jogador utilize estratégias diferentes
+Engraçado
+Multiplayer com vários modos e mapas

Contras:
-Sistema de tentativa e erro é irritante
-Combates repetitivos
-Trilha sonora fraca
-Não explica como cada equipamento funciona e diferenças entre eles
-Singleplayer maçante

21502091.review:
Upon typing this up I realized how hard it actually is to describe Cobalt. But I'll try my best. Cobalt is a platform-shooter game. There's singleplayer modes and multiplayer modes, as most of you have come to expect in shooter games. But Cobalt adds in battle mechanics that are not comparable to any other game. There's rolling, extremely satasfying (I probably spelt that wrong, didn't I?) matrix-style slow mo, more rolling, interesting aiming mechanics, more rolling, and generally just a lot of rolling.

 The keyboard controls seem a tiny bit weird at first- seems a little more like a browser game then a Steam game- but I've actually gotten used to it after not very long, and you can modify them if you're not happy. There's also different ways to play the game. There's campaign, which can be played by yourself or with someone else too. There's local multiplayer, which can be played by yourself against bots or with people on your wi-fi. And of course, there's multiplayer, which needs no explination. There's also gamemodes for multiplayer (local and normal multiplayer), which is where it gets interesting.

Free For all is self explanitory- everyone for themselves. There are team options though.

Team Strike is team deathmatch but with class options. Think of Battlefield but the match only lasts 3 minutes at most. You buy "classes" with points gained from winning.

Plug Slam is football with guns. You get a plug and try and put it into the opposite team's goal. 

Survival Mode is where you have to fight off waves of robots. Yeah, I don't know a lot about this gamemode.

Combat and speed challenges are quite interesting. Combat challenges are where you are given a task, e.g. rescue 3 hostages, and are given a score by the time it took you to do it and the efficency (how many enemy bots you killed, how much damage you took, etc.)

Speed challenges are where you have to get from point A to point B in the quickest time possible. There may or may not be enemies in your way.

Campaign is also a lot of fun. You play as Agent Cobalt who is trying to find out what happened to a human settlement. But there's more to it. You can go to dances for no reason whatsoever, roll, train endlessly for combat even though you are already a master at it, roll, make friends with birds and feel bad about life when they die, and more rolling. I hope you like rolling, cause if you do you're in for a treat with this game.

9/10

21497324.review:
2Dプラットフォームアクションですが、装備やシステムはややFPSに近いです。
特に移動関連の動作がよく出来ていて、
斜面を転がったり、爆風をあえて受けたり、ノックバックの強い武器で地面を殴ったりすることで、
普通に歩く速さの数倍、場合によっては二桁倍の速さで動き回ることができます。
他にも銃弾をローリングで、グレネードをパンチで跳ね返せたり、着地時の衝突で防御を崩したりとアクション性が極めて高いです。

ただ、照準はマウスではなくAimボタンによる自動照準です。
自動照準というとAIMというFPSの重要な要素の一つを潰していると思われるかもしれませんが,
前述のローリングによる銃弾の反射などもあるので撃った者勝ちということもなく、駆け引きが熱いです。
またローリングによって360度方向に撃つことは出来るので状況次第で直打ちしたほうが良い場面もあります、
むしろ地面を殴ることによる加速に至っては基本ローリングによる擬似Aimが基本です。

また、通常、高速移動といっても目に見えないことはないので
移動先の読みやすい高速移動はは置き撃ちに弱く、加速するとやや損なので引き気味になりかねませんが
自動照準を振り切るという加速のメリットによって銃弾の反射と合わせて速度の価値を見事に抑えています。

弾丸やグレネードなどが当たりそうになると時間がゆっくりになるいわゆるバレットタイムがあるので
ハイペースなゲームにありがちな
人体スペックが追いつかずマヌケを晒すという失態が起こりづらく
理想のプレーがし易いです。
是非とも対人戦をしたいところですが、パブリックだと殆どサーバが立っていないのが難点です。

高速移動によるゴリ押しプレーだけでなく
装備によってはステルスゲームのようなこともでき
ケツの穴を踏みまくることによって野生動物を手懐けることもできます。
物理的な動作もよく出来ていて移動以外にもその辺の箱で敵も潰せます。
他にもショップの店員を殺害して盗んだりと自由度は中々高いです。
他のゲームに無いわけではありませんが、操作性と丁寧なレベルデザインも相まって十分に面白いです。

全体的に手段も豊富で再現性も低いので作業化しづらくリプレイ性が高いです。
手段が豊富過ぎて凡庸な印象もやや否めませんが
システムもマップのデザインも丁寧で非情に素晴らしいです。
もうこれはスマートでハイペースです。

不満なのは手なづけた野生動物がドアを開ける邪魔になったり
時折出てくる鍵開けパズルが作業だったり
投擲と近接は役割が明確なのに銃だけ似たり寄ったりの武器が複数あったり
速く動けるのにマップごとが小さめだったり
リプレイ性が高いのにストーリーの最初からしかリプレイできないところですが
細かい部分だけで
肝心の根本的な
ゲーム内容はおすすめです。

21493058.review:
I have to mention that I was in the alpha, but i'm not a fanboy.

Cobalt has excellent combat that still gets better as we speak thanks to continues development. Sometimes auto-aim can be a drag but you'll get used to it and work with it.
There is online multiplayer but not many people playing, so probably local is the way to go. Online is certainly possible and fun, only it's possible to have 0 people online.
The story is alright. The level design is a bit open so sometimes you fall or die and then there will be some boring backtracking and finding your way. The story is fully 2 player coop so that's good.
I don't know why everybody hates the keyboard controlls. I own four xbox360 gamepads, but I prefer to play this game with the keyboard. It works fine to me.
There are challengen you can complete which are pretty fun.
The game isn't too expensive, maybe wait for a sale but that could take a while. The game is pretty new in the time of this review.
Maps are lots and can be made yourself with the level editor. It's a little hard to use but you'll find out how it works. Just remember to check the wiki if you don't know what to do.

I really like this game thanks to the combat, the keyboard controlls work fine to me and I'm pretty good (not to brag or anything). The story is ok and there are not many people playing online, but local multiplayer and challenges are the best way to experience this game

21480231.review:
I've been playing this game since day 1, when they released the first alpha build. I can honestly say it's in my top 10 games of all time. I have 100s of hours not logged on steam from all the years. 

The two main parts of the game, that make it stand out from all other titles, is: Slow-Mo and Rolling. These two mechanics combine to make one of the most unique and satisfying experiences I've had in gaming.

With the main points out of the way, some pros:

-Endless replayability.
-Enjoyable learning curve.
-Quirky and beautiful graphics.
-Enough gamemodes to keep you engaged.
-The soundtrack is minimalistic but genius.
-Story mode, which I can't really comment on since I haven't completed, but so far it's great.
-Local Co-op, so if you've got some friends to play with it takes the game from awesome to REALLY awesome.
-Tooooons of different weapons to get acquainted with, everything from machine guns to scimitars, sticky mines to plasma pistols, tazers to wrenches, rocket launchers to sniper rifles, and everything in between. No matter your preferred combat style, your needs will be met with the vast array of weaponry. Not to mention other gadgets to augment your experience, such as jet shoes and shields.
-You can ride giant carniverous space hamsters.
-Steam Workshop, so users can make maps.
-The best pro is that there are no cons.

So yeah. I urge anyone who's looking for a fresh kind of game to pick it up right now. Worth every cent.

UPDATE: Still play this game every week.

21213367.review:
First, remap your buttons if you're on a keyboard to what they were in the alpha.

Z: roll, X: attack, C: auto-aim, V: reload, A: melee, S: ranged, D: throwables, arrow keys for movement. These are much better than the default ones in Gold edition IMO.

Cobalt is the very definition of a mixed bag. The best way to describe Cobalt is as an engine. This game manages to juggle a story mode, an arcade mode with bots and local multiplayer, an online version of said arcade mode, and an extensive, albeit hard-to-use level editor that lets you replicate nearly everything if not everything that can be done in the normal maps. Because that's what Cobalt is: an engine. The combat system is very unique with rolling and the addition of auto aim, (which is not analogous to aim-bot; it has time-to-aim, innacuracy, etc.) The giant roster of weapons and equippables is nothing to scoff at, and lost but not least it's all moddable to my knowledge.

Some negative reviewers have voiced distaste in the game because they bought the game for 1 reason, i.e. to play the story mode and only the story mode, which, while the story mode is good by itself, it's by no means the whole game, and you're very much limiting your enjoyment if you only experience one way the engine has been used. Story mode is extensive but it doesn't even show all the mechanics the game has, albeit most of them. The best thing I can tell you to do is, after story mode, play some of the arcade modes, and then try to play local/online multiplayer if there are players for either. And if you're feeling particularily invested try out the editor for yourself; there aren't many online guides but there should be enough to get you started.

21209449.review:
This is my first review for a game. I don't usually write reviews, but I felt like I should weigh in on this.

Bottom-line: this game's good. 

It's pretty difficult, but it depends on your skill as a player, rather than artificial difficulties (like traps, attacks you couldn't see coming, etc). The music's nice and atmospheric, and keeps up the tension as you explore the game world, looking to avoid getting overwhelmed by multiple soldiers. The graphics are crisp and high-detail, and the game's pretty well optimized, to boot. 

The multiplayer's surprisingly lagfree and is pretty deep, as well - for example, rolling can change how and when you attack, and also reflects bullets. So it's pretty much mandatory if you want to play singleplayer, even more-so online. However, rolling all of the time becomes a burden, like dodging or blocking all of the time in a fighting game, as when you're in a roll, you can't stop rolling, and a shot that hits your feet will damage you. So you have to mix it up, time your rolls, and move around to avoid dying, haha.

There's a ton to do in the game, and there's room for improvement, as there's also additional game modes that are present on the Workshop maps. For example, Classic Survival mode is not like the regular Survival mode. In Classic Survival, you don't face off against discrete waves, but rather deal with enemies as you explore the game map, searching hidden alcoves and safes for loot and weapons. Classic Survival's probably my favorite game mode, haha.

Anyway, my opinion's that this game is EASILY worth more than $20. Get it!

21193101.review:
I remember when this game was announced around 2011 and I was really excited to try it out and I'm happy that it finally came to Steam, sad thing that it took such a long time to be released. Nonetheless, let's talk about the game itself -- the graphics are pretty, the soundtrack is amazing and the gameplay is quite unique; despite the bullet time, it's a really fast paced game that requires a lot of precision, reflex, teamwork and strategy. 

There are dozens of weapons and game modes, making it even more enjoyable and not as repetitive. Since there are so many mechanics that you need to understand and improve, every match is a different experience as you get progressively better, be it at dodging, at aiming, moving around the map and whatnot.

It might take a while for some people to get used to the controls, especially if you're on the keyboard (some prefer a controller, since you don't have a mouse aiming system) but it's no big deal, they respond well and that's enough for the gameplay to be smooth. Even when you're playing in a room where you've ~200 ping, the match is still enjoyable. 

Altogether, the game is amazing, has a lot of mechanics and technics that you can get good at, an awesome soundtrack that fits very well and simple but elegant graphics. I would totally recommend it, especially if you can gather your friends to play with, as with every game, it's way more enjoyable with someone you know.

21164951.review:
On paper, Cobalt is fairly simple. You are a robot dude, and you shoot other robot dudes and things. When a bullet, grenade or other hazard comes close, time locally slows down around you, giving you time to punch that grenade back, deflect that bullet or pull some otherwise epic combo. Trust me, this is way more fun than it sounds.

With the high skill ceiling on all aspects of the game (timing shots, throwing bombs, punch jumping, etc) there is a lot to learn but the game is pretty easy to pick up and has plenty of things to do such as a detailed campaign, speedrun challenges (against the rest of the world), wave survival, plug football (except you can throw it) and good old deathmatch.

Brilliant gameplay, and I also like the graphics style. I would recommend this to anyone who likes action and pulling cool stunts and general awesomeness. There is plenty for both competitive and casual players.

Get it. Get it now.

21148264.review:
Bien réalisé graphiquement, game feel sensationel, contenu correct et surtout potentiellement infini avec l'éditeur de maps : Cobalt est un très bon jeu!

La plupart des évaluations négatives portent sur les "mauvais contrôles", c'est assez drôle sachant que tout est configurable avec une grande souplesse. J'avoue que j'ai passé pas mal de temps à trouver un binding qui me convient, mais une fois votre gamepad configuré (au clavier c'est possible de jouer mais plus dur) et un peu de temps passé à s'entraîner, ce jeu devient satisfaisant, impressionant et vraiment fun!

La seule reproche que je lui fais c'est de mal utiliser son potentiel, en effet le contenu proposé est utilisé de manière assez annecdotique alors qu'une vraie profondeur est exploitable, il faut compter sur le workshop pour nous proposer de nouvelles possibilités!

La campagne est un peu étrange mais pas trop facile ni extrêmement dure. Le plus fun c'est surtout les parties entre potes, et même seul contre des IA (pas si débiles par rapport à d'autres jeux). 
En plus si on se montre créatif, chaque map peut être exploitée de plusieurs façons : on peut se mettre en FFA ou par teams, se mettre seul contre 10 de bots, utiliser une classe différente de celle qui est prévue pour la map et plus encore!
De plus on a pas mal de modes de jeux différents pour varier les plaisirs!

Je recommande Cobalt globalement mais j'aimerais mettre en garde les casus : c'est un jeu difficile à prendre en main qui vas demmander de l'entraînement et qui pourra vous satisfaire si vous prenez la peine de toucher à tout, la première experience n'est pas toujours très emballante, parfois votre patience sera mise à l'épreuve mais il faut se montre mature (dans sa conception du gaming) pour kiffer un maximum!

21083150.review:
Everything is better with bullet time, and Cobalt is no exception. Oxeye's run-and-gun platformer has action, charm, and humour by the spadeload and is absolutely worth the asking price. It also has giant sabertooth space hamsters!

Battles in both singleplayer and online are chaotic and will often have unpredictable and hilarious outcomes, but you never feel that you've lost control. Time slows down as bullets and grenades get close to you, giving you the opportunity to execute a pixel-perfect dodge or perhaps even punch a grenade right back at whoever threw it! Facing a hail of bullets? No problem: do a combat roll straight into them and reflect them off the top of your robot's armoured head!

Although some people have commented that you need a gamepad, I'm getting on just fine with keyboard controls. For a right-handed person the defaults are pretty logical if you spend a couple of minutes in the tutorial to learn them, and are remappable if you find them awkward.

21065487.review:
Con más de 300 horas jugadas, creo que ha llegado el momento de refinar mi revisión sobre uno de mis videojuegos favoritos y para mí, el más rejugable y adictivo de 2016.

Empezaré hablando de su punto fuerte, el multijugador.
Puedes jugar multijugador online o LAN, como prefieras. Incluso si te apetece, puedes retar a tus amigos de steam a que os venzan a tí y a tus amigos en tu casa. Aunque digan lo que digan, Cobalt está hecho para disfrutarlo en el sofá de tu salón, con tus colegas mientras os echáis unas risas compitiendo en los diferentes modos de juego: Team Strike, Deathmatch, Plug Slam y el más reciente en multijugador, el modo Survival.

Team Strike: Duelo por equipos. Batalla campal. Si os lo montáis bien puede quedar una buena escena de acción. Gana el equipo que logre reventar al contrario. Al comienzo de cada ronda puedes comprar, vender, reparar o mejorar tu equipamiento. Este equipamiento viene dado por lotes predefinidos por el mapa que se pueden editar, como ejemplo, una clase con rifle de asalto y una cegadora, o un palo de madera y granadas.

Deathmatch: Todos contra todos. Perfecto si tu grupo de amigos es impar. En este caso no existe equipamiento... las armas aparecen en el mapa. Si el objetivo era pelearse ahora además tendréis que pelearos por coger esa dichosa arma que tanto os gusta a todos.

Plug Slam: Volleyball a lo bestia. El balón aparece en medio del mapa, esperando a que marques un satisfactorio gol que acaba con una explosión de luz y contigo volando con una preciosa estela del color de tu equipo... ¡Boom!

Survival: Sobrevivir a oleadas de enemigos que pasarán de darte puntos para comprar equipamiento a darte motivos para no salir sin tu escudo.

Hablaré del modo historia, aunque solo me lo he pasado una vez. A mi parecer, algo prescindible, no me ha dado muchas horas de juego, aunque sí que me lo he pasado bastante bien. Es perfecto para hacerte con la idea del juego, las mecánicas y la física tras él, si no te fue suficiente con el tutorial. Además, el trasfondo no es uno cualquiera. Si te gusta la ciencia ficción no perderás el tiempo.
No es un simple modo historia, sino que además trae consigo niveles de desafío puzzle, contrarreloj y de combate, a los que puedes jugar también fuera del modo campaña y conseguir logros completándolos todos. 

Hablando de logros, Cobalt tiene un montón. Para algunos necesitas haber jugado a todos los modos de juego, y otros implican colaboración de amigos.

Si tu intención es pasar el rato jugando a este juego, prepárate para que pasen horas y horas. 

Los únicos puntos malos del juego son la frecuencia con la que este es actualizado y la practicamente inexistente comunidad que lo sigue. Es frustrante entrar al modo multijugador y no ver a nadie jugando casi nunca, y ver que desde que lo compraste no lo han actualizado ninguna vez. Pero no le quita la diversión que traen sus mecánicas. 9/10

21010777.review:
Wow, I have so many things to say I don't know where to start.

I started playing this game during its Alpha release, and from the moment I finished the tutorial, I knew this game had great potential. Not only was a stellar team working tirelessly to put such a complex game together, they were streaming their development process; There was always open communication between the devs and the community. Not only this, but they were backed by Mojang- A new testament to the reliability of small-team game developement.

Cobalt is a game of reflex, maneuverability and precision. There is no shortage of skills and strategy to be employed and the skill ceiling will leave casual gamers and veterans alike in awe of the possibilities of team composition, movement, vantage points, and finger dexterity.

One of the coolest features of Cobalt is the Time Dialation mechanic which slows time locally (relevant to each player) giving players more time to react to incoming projectiles. It is this mechanic (which I assume was a pain in the ass to get working consistantly for multiplayer) which enables players to perform feats which would simply be impossible in other platformer/shooters. 

There is a copious amount of weapons, accessories, and characters ensuring that every thinkable playstyle can be catered to and employed successfully. This is especially useful for players hoping to customize their online experience, essentially allowing users to create their own classes in multiplayer matches and by extension, a new meta game for each lobby you join.

Fans of PVP gameplay will get hours of enjoyment from this title. A true test of gaming skill. Marvelous. Simply marvelous.

20988286.review:
I've owned Cobalt for quite some time, since it was first released in Alpha. Back when Mojang could do no wrong and Notch was a god in the gaming world.
It's a tight little action platformer, with fairly unique mechanics and deep gameplay. Had a lack of content, polish, and major bugs, but the core concept was solid. I played it on and off for a few months, then forgot about it for years until it got its full release on Steam. I redeemed my code from the alpha version, and tried it out.
This game, at a 20$ price point, is unbuyable. It lacks content, and has so many game breaking bugs I would call it an Alpha rather than a full release. I've crashed no less than 16 times playing for a little over an hour, and encountered odd lag in multiplayer. The controls for keyboard are awful, and overcomplicated, so I played on controller, which was mediocre at best. The story seems fine, albeit not voice acted or interesting apart from the gameplay, and the multiplayer is night unplaybly buggy. The funnest part of Alpha Cobalt was removed (the survival mode, like Horde mode/COD Zombies), so I can't really rate that. This game has good core gameplay, but lacks in controls, stability, and content.
If this were priced at 10$, you might actually find some people to play with in the multiplayer, which is dead (3-4 players online at peak hours.). I got a good game of multiplayer in with 6 others once, and that was fun. For now, I'm going to give this game a thumbs down. 
People who like the idea of this game, try out Duck Game. It's great. Really great.

20982229.review:
Cobalt is a platformer with fantastically well designed and carefully fine tuned mechanics that are as deep and complex as any platformer I've ever played. A full length story driven single player game with characters and tons of different weapons, equipment and variety in it's level design both from an aesthetic and mechanical perspective.

The character moves at the perfect speed to have the option of chaining together exhilarating moves such as deflecting bullets back at enemies while dodging others and shooting down alarms if you can time the moves correctly.

It feels like it was "finished" years ago by the standards of most games and rather than polishing it up and releasing it, the devs decided to fine tune and add depth, content and features, perhaps without the pressure of money running out with the backing of Mojang's millions.

On top of all of that the multiplayer game is anything but a tacked on extra. It's a game in itself that could easily rival any of the duck games, samurai gunns, nidhoggs or towerfalls of the last few years.

I haven't looked in to the possibilities for user generated content yet but with workshop support as well I'm glad I bought in.

Probablemente este juego nunca llegue al grado de popularidad que se merece, aunque si lo hace me alegraré mucho.

A simple vista parece otro shotter mas en 2D, pero no lo es, tiene dos puntos clave realmente favorecedores que son: el tiempo bala y el auto-apuntado con un solo botón.

Probablemente lo segundo pueda parecer un coñazo por lo mal acostumbrados que estamos al autoapuntado en shotters en 3D pero creedme, en este juego esta tan bien implementado junto con el tiempo bala que lo hace realmente atractivo y gratificante en cada muerte.

Llevo jugando a este juego desde que supe de el, lo compré un poco "a ciegas" pero le vi potencial y la alpha la disfruté mucho, he seguido su desarrollo desde entonces.

Puede parecer un poco caro de primeras pero con la multitud de modos de juego que trae y con el modo historia estan realmente compensados...encajar un modo historia en condiciones en un juego como este supone todo un reto y desde luego que este juego cumple con creces en ese apartado, yo solo esperaba su versión definitiva para jugarlo por fin online pero tengo que decir que el modo historia me ha sorprendido muchisimo y para bien, no es un simple "mata mata" te mete de lleno en el lore del juego y además lo hace con humor, un toque de libertad de acción y un poco de misterio.

Echo en falta un multijugador mas pulido con rankings y demás, pero aún así es divertidisimo, pocos modos de juego en multi pero cada uno es muy diferente al anterior por no hablar de cada una de las variantes, no es lo mismo jugar en su modo mas clasico de disparos que hacerlo en "modo medieval" utilizando solo armas de melee y granadas...y lo mejor, es que las granadas se pueden devolver con cada golpe de melee :D

Lo dicho, estoy encantado con este juego y con su multi, me dió muchas horas en su versión alpha y ahora  no será distinto, lo que mas juego es el multijugador y la verdad es que lo vale, pero tiene tantos modos para jugar en solitario y en multi que de una forma u otra seguro que algunto te acaba gustando aunque la base del juego no termine de convencerte.

20958708.review:
I discovered Cobalt a few years back at Minecon 2013, Jens and the other developers at Oxeye were operating a pretty cool panel about the game. Fast forward two weeks, I had purchased the alpha of the game and vested a good 20 hours into it.

Cobalt's emergence from alpha has been a progressive and evident one. This 'version 1.0' of Cobalt is chuck-full of features that make the game limitless in fun and interest: multiplayer is awesome, and the story mode is quite imaginative as far as platformers go. The map designs by the developers are just the tip of the iceberg, as you can design your own maps & levels.

$20 is not too much, might I add, for a game that has this extensive amount of gameplay. I have already sunk countless hours, and I'm not kidding when I say this game is still highly playable after 2 and a half years of playing it. It has a novelty, succession of updates, and evident quality.

That doesn't necessarily mean that Cobalt is 110% awesome, however. There is a learning curve and rather difficult controls. However, some messing around and patience is sure to get you a control setup you will enjoy. I find that anyone that complains of the game's controls has always proven impatient or ends up enjoying the game once they grasp the understand of 'how to play.' The great thing is that the controls are customizable and I understand gamepad support is available.

Overall, the game has an outstanding blend of fast-pace and slow-mo shooting action, accompanied by some great creative direction in design. As far as platformers go, there are few as good as Cobalt. As far as [i]combat[/i] platformers go, there are none as good as Cobalt. The novelty, playability, design, and organic gameplay that Cobalt provides is one of the most unique and imaginative platformers around. You will not be disappointed.

The challenges were the most stressful, but at the same time fun, mode of the game. And they still are. A bunch of maps with some complex game mechanics and true action combat, perfect to train and improve our abilities in the game 'cause the AI is merciless and you are squishy as little bunny.
    [*][b]Deathmatch[/b]
This is good to train yourself in an ambient with permanent action and to think how things works in Cobalt. What the weapons do, how take intense moments were if you miss your shoot you die and loss... Pretty intense and insanely fun.
    [*][b]Team-Strike[/b]
The deathmatch for friends, to hate your friends or try to humiliate the AI... if you can, like I said before. The AI is respectable and pretty hardcore if you want it to be. The bots just know the perfect aim, time and everything else to destroy you and give an incredible match.
    [*][b]Plug Slam[/b]
The Plug Slam is the classic Capture the Flag, but adding throwing! You must go to the rival base and get their Plug while defending yours from them. The first one to retrieve it to his own base get a point and the games are played at the best of three. It’s a nice mode thank to the gorgeous maps and the throwing and rolling, if you domain them. It puts this classic mode in a new level of strategic that is worth the try.
    [*][b]Survival[/b]
Survive waves of enemies, put yourself at the limit of patience and fail a lot. Protect Bopo Brains may be easy at first, but you must choose well your equipment or the next horde will be the last. Pretty different from the original Classic Survival, which was some class of sandbox map, the Survival puts out the exploration to give space the action and preparation to the next challenge. A really nice and recommendable mode to try yourself in huge hordes of enemies scenarios.
[/list]
I must say, also, that you can add all kind of map to the already large amount of maps, and that the Classic Survival (That I love) is not dead and you can play it from the workshop in maps made from the community.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]

Now that you know the mods of the game, is the turn of the amazing mechanics to play it.
The Tutorial sums up pretty much of them, giving you interactive practice to get along with the controls and try them the times you want. It also explains the advanced things like Roll to shoot up or how to even punch rockets to redirect them. Passing the Tutorial is not enough to master this… but at least it lets you know about them and it’s something not many games do at the day.

The most basic tool is the Rolling which lets you do almost anything. Get speed is one of the advantages but bouncing back the enemy bullets it’s priceless, especially when one of them actually kills the shooter that tries to kill you first! You will find you rolling all the time in the end.

Also, the game values al sort of strategic you can think. From being a Tank, armed with shields and Rolls that let no one harm you… or be a sneaky shadow and get you enemies from the back. You can Climb walls and hide, or climb them and disappear from the sight of the enemy. And if you make a bad roll and didn’t bounce back some bullets there’s no problem because you get a second chance as the Brain inside your robot, flying clumsy around trying to reconstruct yourself.

There are LOTs of ways to play this game and that’s another reason why I recommend it. You can play the way you want, or all the ways if you want!

[b][u]Map Edition[/u][/b]
The map edition is one of the finest things about the game because the huge materials and possibilities it gives. You can make simple arena maps or put your life on it and do the most complex thing you ever do. The possibilities are almost infinite with it and it’s proven in the Workshop where from a few days of the launch it blows of maps and things that the community has made.

You have all the tiles, all the NPCs, all the weapons and all the tools to make your Challenge, Deathmatch, Survival, PlugSlam or whatever youwant-map here (Just for the little price of a headache, maybe(?))

[b][u]Controller Support, Co-Operative Play (Online or Local), Achievements and Workshop[/u][/b]

All of this just sums up for the game and make it worth the investment even more if you play with friends. The Story can be played either alone or with someone; the same is for the other game modes. If none of your friends have the game the Local play is equally fun and the Controller support make it easy to set up.

The Controller Support is amazing, even if you didn’t use an Xbox Controller, with a PS2 Controller and the adapter you are ready to go an configure it the way you like. The customization is core in this game.

The Achievements brings you nice challenges to get better and better and there are a lot of them. And Workshop has one of the best community’s I ever see, with awesome maps and things to share.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]

From my point of view, Cobalt has a lot to give and it’s totally worth to give a chance if you like the kinetic fast passed shooting combat with rolls, climbs and a bunch of things to do. The game was amazing during the Alpha, and now that it is released is a total blast.

It will not let you down.

20944746.review:
To me this game is already a timeless classic.

Story: 8/10. A solid plot with plenty of humour. Not a masterpiece, but the story is conveyed excellently through the campaign style. Story mode is not the primary focus of Cobalt, but it is a lengthy, challenging and rewarding campaign. The lore behind the game is intriguing and leaks through into some of the arcade mode maps, which I think is a really nice touch.

Graphics: 9/10. It's not beautiful pixel art and it's no Mona Lisa, but playing some of the custom maps completely convinced me that this game can look really amazing.

Sound: 9/10. The music is catchy and memorable and the sound fx perfectly match what is happening in-game, slowing down when the time dilation kicks in. I can't think of anything I would change here.

Gameplay: Beyond 10. In an age of games where the gameplay is often left to one side, Cobalt turns around and says "here's what it means to be a gameplay focused game." The entire game is physical and feels very natural after a while at the controls. There are really endless possibilities to what can be done inside the Cobalt engine, which is why I'm incredibly excited to see that there are already modding possibilities. Never before have I played a game that creates so many awesome moments. Doing a backflip over a missile whilst shooting your gun at a grenade so it bounces off a wall and into another player is just tame to me now. This is the game that will make you squeal, will make you sweat and will make you feel like the most awesome person in the universe.

Cobalt sets the bar for gameplay now. Forget Mario, forget Smash Bros, forget every other game under the sun. I will never be able to look at another game again the same way. If you think this is just another arena brawler like Duck Game and Towerfall then think again. I can't play those kind of games anymore without thinking "man, I'd rather just be playing Cobalt."

I bought this game in alpha and forgot about it until just today when I saw it on friggin steam!

But as a forenote/TL;DR: THIS GAME IS FOR THOSE WHO LIVE FOR 2D PLATFORM MECHANICAL PVP. IF YOU ARE A METALASSAULT FAN, WAIT UNTIL IT COMES OUT AND PLAY THAT. OTHERWISE, THIS IS A GREAT GAME, DEFINITELY WORTH GRABBING!
       
       This game has come a long way since its alpha, and many, many things have gone from "meh" too "pretty cool!", "sick" , or "sweet dude!".   The combat mechanic is definitely the reason people will end up playing the game, with pros and cons of the game here:

Pros:
-Awesome rolling mechanic, the thing makes combat insanely skill based with infinite outplay potential.
-Slow motion to help out with the sticky situations
-Local and online multiplayer, with options to change game modes, maps, ranked/unranked, etc.
-Story mode, which can get fun at times (more about that in the cons)
-Full controller support with decent mapping and control.

Cons:
-Slow motion in 4 player deathmatch gets really hectic at times, as you may be trying to get into the action, but the other players are constantly in combat, triggering slow-mo for everyone
-Campaign is pretty crap. Story is meh, and it spawns you in a spaceship without telling you much of what to do, kinda like the "find out yourself" vibe that Zelda II: Adventure of Link gave. (whether or not it exists physically, that game doesn't exist in our hearts)

-Controls to switch between weapon types can get overwhelming at times, lots of players are franically switching to grenades instead of their gun or melee weapon, etc. (on controller, I don't use keyboard)

The gameplay is (and always was) super tight with a lot of depth. It's easy to learn but hard to master (you can punch grenades to send them back, well-timed rolls can deflect shots, there is a weird and awesome bulletime system in place...). Which makes this game super fun in local versus. It's a must have if you have friends coming over, like super smash bros on consoles.
Each match can be customized like crazy (which robot you're playing, stage music, available weapons,...)

I didn't play much with the solo modes yet but so far I like what I see. The story seems fun and humorous and you can upgrade/customize your character, which is something I didn't expect at all (it kinda give an RPG feel to the game). There also seem to hav a lot of little interactivity thingy which I really like (you can mount certain creatures, get a bird and see it dies by a rocket 5 seconds after,...)

I tried some of the challenges and that seems to be fun, there is a leaderboard so you can compare your score to other players and try to be the best (carefull, it's addictive as hell since a challenge doesn't take more than 30 seconds) ;)

The sound design is amazing, musics are nice and you won't believe how much diversity the devs could offer you with "blip", "bloup" and "biip" sounds.

Apparently you can unlock things, which I always appreciate.

So... well done devs. Your game was amazing 5 years ago, and you managed to make it even better now :)

20923103.review:
First Impressions Video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j8m_prqz0g4

Cobalt surprised me.  I came in expecting another side scrolling shooter and found a much more intricate and complex design with some real character to it.  The graphical design is stylized and matched by ambient as well as beat heavy music.  The audio thump of weapons firing, punches connecting and robots being gibbed is satisfying every single time.
It is easy to tell that this is a labour of love.  Oxeye has been working on this game for 6 years, and it shows.  With multiple single player and multiplayer methods of playing, and the idea of having a full toolset to make your own levels is really cool.  So far, this title is an interesting diamond in the rough.

That’s not to say that it is without problems.  The review build I was provided by Oxeye seems to not recognize options changes.  I couldn’t change resolution or graphical quality.  The toolset opened to scripting errors and I did have the occasional crash when attempting to make options adjustments.

All of that said, for $20 you can do a hell of a lot worse and if it gets a large enough install base to where the multiplayer maintains an active community, I could see this game lasting quite some time to take advantage of those free updates Oxeye has promised.  I look forward to seeing what else Mojang might consider publishing.

20921668.review:
[h1][b]Cobalt[/b] - Игра, которая мне понравилась с самой первой доступной Alpha версии![/h1]

Игра была разработана студией [b][i]Oxeye Game Studio[/i][/b] и стала доступна 16 го Декабря, 2011 го года.
Сама игра - Платформер с видом сбоку. В этой игре вам предстоит взять на себя роль железного
парня, агента Кобальта, который обнаружил давно утерянный колонизационный корабль [i]"The Seed"[/i] организации
[i]"Space Exploration Foundation"[/i] на планете Trunkopia. Этот корабль был построен на Земле много лет назад,
но с ним была потеряна связь спустя 30 минут с момента перехода в постпространство.
Дальнейшая судьба корабля и его экипажа неизвестна. Теперь Кобальту предстоит исследовать свою находку и
столкнуться с любой опасностью, обитающей внутри.

Кроме основного режима [i]"Приключения"[/i], в котором и предоставлен сам сюжет игры, есть и другие режимы игры,
такие как [i]Deathmatch, Capture the Plug, Classic Survival, Waves Survival, Team-Strike, и Challenge.[/i]

[b]Deathmatch[/b] - Режим игры в котором каждый игрок сам за себя.
Тот игрок, который сделает больше всех убийств - победитель. Оружия следует искать на игровом пространстве.

[b]Capture the Plug[/b] - Или по другому (Capture the Flag). 
Этот же режим игры вы можете вспомнить из легендарной Unreal Tournament.
Игроки делятся на две команды - Красные и Синие. 
Задача каждой команды украсть вражеский "Плуг", и принести его на свою базу.
Если игрок который нёс Плуг погибает, то он его выбрасывает.
Если выброшенный Плуг подбирает союзник, то тот может донести вражеский Плуг до своей базы.
А если выброшенныый Плуг подбирает враг, то его Плуг моментально возвращается на базу.

[b]Classic Survival[/b] - Режим игры на одного игрока.
Задача только одна - Продержаться как можно дольше и накопить как можно больше вольт(Вольты - это игровая валюта).
Уничтожайте врагов, собирайте лут, переводите лут в Вольты, осматривайте территорию, покупайте оружия,
покупайте костюмы, улучшайте всё это, и просто, постарайтесь набрать как можно больше Вольт. Конца игры не будет.
Это кстати мой любимый режим из второстепенных.

[b]Waves Survival[/b] - Режим игры на одного игрока.
Этот режим немножко напоминает Classic Survival, но всё же отличий больше. Вам нужно будет выдерживать волны противников.
Чтобы волна закончилась вам надо просто уничтожить всех противников на карте. 
После окончания волны вас отправляют в магазин, где вы сможете купить свое оружие, или улучшить костюм.

[b]Team-Strike[/b] - Это тоже самое, что и Counter Strike. (Только нет заложников и взрывчатки.)
Две команды - Красные, и Синие. В самом начале раунда обе команды делают свой начальный закуп, а затем начинается и сам бой.
Цель обеих команд - Уничтожить всю противоположную команду.

[b]Challenge[/b] - Режим игры в котором вам нужно постараться добраться из одной точки в другую за какое то время.
Нужно постараться это сделать как можно быстрее. Также есть вид карт в которых вам необходимо освободить заложников тоже за время.

Кроме всего этого в игре присутствует система достижений. Кому то это очень важно, ведь это тоже действительно интересно!
В игре есть встроенный редактор Карт, Миров, Галактик, Искусственного интеллекта, Мира, Приключения и Разделов!
С помощью всех этих редакторов можно устроить свой собственный сюжет со своими головоломками, планетами, командами, врагами и много чего другим.
Возможности редактора могут удивить любого! Пользоваться редактором не составит труда. Главное привыкнуть.

Композитор игры тоже постарался замечательно! Каждая музыка услышанная в игре может подойти под окружение, и это действительно классно!
У врагов, союзников и всех персонажей легко настраиваемый искусственный интеллект, который можно настроить так, как вам будет удобно.
Используя редактор, вы сможете сделать много фракций, у которых будут свои собственные отличительные способности, такие как мораль, настроение, и многе другое!
Да да! Всем персонажем можно изменять настроение и эмоции!

В редакторе карт вы сможете построить всё что вам угодно, от огромных баз до красивой природы. Единственное ограничение - Это ваша фантазия.

Некоторым игра может напомнить The Eler Scrolls

Вы сможете создать карту для любого режима игры, и загрузить её в Мастерскую Steam'a.

Игра 10 / 10! Поиграйте каждый! Пройдите обучение, и начните игру! Вам она не понравится, если вы не попробуете поиграть подольше!
Испробуйте каждый режим, и пройдите Кампанию! Удачной игры, агент Кобальт!

20918019.review:
While I may have little time in the steam version, I have owned this game for many years.
Cobalt is an action side scrolling game with great combat mechanics. 
The story, so far, is great and has a metroidvania feel to it. While not hard to find, the story contains some secret areas with powerful weapons or loot that are rewarding to find. The story also contains a few puzzles such as searching the area for a "plug" to put inside of a slot to advance or, as I’ve seen so far, three different kinds of lock picking. One where it is stylistic of a tradition lock with the pins and you have to listen for a click, one with the rotation locks that you'd see on a locker where you turn it until you hear a click then turn in the opposite direction, and one where it plays you a tune and you have to adjust some notes until you match it. There are also boss battles that are very fun to do. The story is great and while giving you a decent amount of lives it can still be challenging as you can die very quickly and in rapid succession if you’re not careful. As I have not gone too far into the story I can’t comment anymore about it but i have picked up blue prints and I know there is an upgrade/blueprint mechanic. There is also a hub area on your ship where you select which mission youd like to do.

The fighting mechanics are some of the best I’ve ever seen in a game, just take a look at the videos. There is so much to learn how different weapons react to many different variables. Such as how you can shoot a grenade back at your opponent or how you can roll the bullets away. There is lots of freedom in movement which is great.

Now for the couch co-op/multiplayer/single player with AI games such as "death match" "plug slam" and "team strike" they are a ton of fun to play with others. in all these game modes you can select a starting character to keep things new and switch weapons out on the map. Also i forgot to mention, there is a very nice array of weapons.
-death match: your standard death match game as you would assume.
-plug slam: a 1 flag CTF style game mode but usually in a small area. Changed from the standard ctf mode of the ALPHA on decent sized maps, this new tweak seems to try to make the game faster paced. You spawn with a plug in the middle and try to "slam" it into the other person’s goal. This can be done by shooting it, throwing it, creating an explosion by it to propel it, or anything else this game allows you to do. You can also shoot the plug away from your own goal just as you can shoot grenades.
-team strike: a usual 8 player game mode where you get one life and can get upgrades on your class before each round with money from kills. a lot of fun and it makes you change up your play style a bit since you have one life. Probably my favorite game mode but i have not gotten too far into the tweaked new CTF game mode.

Challenge modes are also in the game. For the competitive player. There is leader board to see who has the highest combat score in combat challenges and fastest completion speed in speed challenges where you try to complete a level as fast as you can.

There is much more I could type about but this is the main points. I skipped over a lot. Check out the tutorial videos on the basic of "offence" and "defence" to see some more.
